title: Accenture unveils $4 billion share buyback, lifts 2025 revenue guidance by 3-6% on AI-led order boom
description: Accenture hiked it's annual revenue growth forecast to 3-6 per cent for 2025 after the US Federal Reserve's supersized interest rate cut.
content: Accenture unveiled a $4.0 billion share buyback and reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter revenue driven by a high demand from companies looking to adopt generative artificial intelligence (AI) technology.Accenture hiked its annual revenue growth forecast to 3-6 per cent for 2025 after improving macroeconomic indicators and the US Federal Reserve's latest supersized interest rate cut. Accenture follows a September-August financial year.Also Read: GenAI: What Accenture got right, but Indian IT didn'tShares of the information technology (IT) major were up nearly seven per cent in premarket trading. The Dublin-based company reported fourth-quarter revenue of $16.41 billion, an increase of three per cent in US dollars and five per cent in local currency, slightly better than nalysts' expectations.The GAAP operating margin was 14.3 per cent, an increase of 230 basis points, and the adjusted operating margin was 15 per cent, an increase of 10 basis points. For fiscal year 2025, Accenture expects GAAP EPS of $12.55 to $12.91, an increase of 5-8 percent from adjusted EPS for fiscal 2024.Also Read: Accenture secures GenAI orders worth $2 billion in first nine months of FY24The IT giant's generative AI business, which helped offset the slowdown in demand for tech services, continued to grow for a fourth successive quarter. It has been outpacing the growth in its other core businesses as organizations look for automation to curtail costs and improve efficiency.Accenture's new bookings, a key metric indicating the value of customer contracts with spending commitments, rose to $20.1 billion for the fourth quarter, up from $17.25 billion in the third quarter.According to news agency Reuters, generative AI bookings contributed $1 billion to the company's new bookings, compared to $900 million in the previous quarter. The bookings have shown robust quarter-on-quarter acceleration for the past four quarters, reaching $3 billion for the year.Also Read: IT firms mustnâ€™t miss warning signals from AccentureWhile analysts expect a turnaround in IT services, the expectations for next year remain modest. JP Morgan analysts said they were not as bullish for the sector as last year, adding that clients will continue withholding discretionary spending. Ahead of Accenture's results, Morgan Stanley said the overall demand for IT services will likely be slower than expected in the coming quarters.
